CASE 53:
SELF-HARM
While you are working in Accident and Emergency (A&E) on a Sunday afternoon you are
asked to see Naomi, a 15-year-old ‘regular attendee’. No one else wants to see her. Naomi
is very subdued and has a deep cut along the top of her thigh. Her legs and arms are criss-
crossed with scars. She asks you to just hurry up and ‘practise your suturing’ so that she
can get home in time for a family roast. You are concerned about her blasé attitude to her
injuries. Looking through the notes you discover this is her 18th attendance to A&E in the
past 6 months for similar treatment. You try to talk to Naomi about why she self-harms.
Naomi is surprised, as no one has asked her this before.
Questions
• How should patients who self-harm be managed?
• What can be done to prevent a ‘revolving door’ system of hospital admissions?

data.vignette: You are the ED clinician seeing a 15-year-old who presents with a fresh, deep laceration on her thigh from self-inflicted injury; she has many older scars and has attended repeatedly over recent months for similar wounds. She is calm and insists you “just stitch it quickly” so she can leave for a family meal, and she refuses to discuss why she self-harms or to involve her parent/guardian, saying she does not want “a big fuss.” The wound needs repair and you are worried that treating and discharging her as requested will reinforce a cycle of escalating harm, but holding her longer for a psychosocial assessment may feel coercive, strain trust, and could require breaching confidentiality to ensure follow-up and safety planning. As the treating clinician, you must decide what to recommend now.
data.choice_1: Proceed with wound repair and discharge after brief safety advice, respecting her request to leave and keeping details confidential unless she agrees to share them, while offering voluntary follow-up resources.
data.choice_2: Treat the wound but insist on a same-visit mental health assessment and safety planning before discharge, including involving a parent/guardian or child safeguarding services despite her objections if needed to reduce near-term risk and interrupt the cycle of harm.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove language that implies a clinically certain trajectory or that one option will objectively prevent harm. For example, change “will reinforce a cycle of escalating harm” to “could be perceived as tacitly endorsing ongoing self-harm or miss an opportunity to assess risk,” and change “to reduce near-term risk and interrupt the cycle of harm” to “to allow assessment of near-term risk and consider safety planning.” Avoid framing one pathway as clearly safer or more effective; keep the uncertainty explicit.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add only the missing clinical facts needed to anchor the ethical stakes: (1) whether she is medically stable and the laceration requires sutures vs operative care; (2) brief suicide risk screen findings (e.g., denies/endorses suicidal intent, access to means) without numbers; (3) her apparent decision-making capacity/competence (alert, not intoxicated, understands options); (4) whether a parent/guardian is present/available and any known safeguarding history; (5) whether local policy/law treats this as mandatory safeguarding disclosure. Remove minor decorative details if adding these (e.g., the “family meal” could be shortened to “wants to leave immediately”).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Make Choice 1 clinically/ethically defensible by adding facts that reduce the appearance of mandatory holding/parental notification (e.g., she denies suicidal intent/plan, is medically stable, demonstrates understanding, has imminent outpatient follow-up, and prior forced disclosure worsened safety at home). Also soften Choice 2 from absolute 'insist'/'involve despite objections' to a conditional threshold (e.g., require same-visit assessment; involve guardian/safeguarding only if imminent risk or inability to ensure safe discharge).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove value-laden or outcome-leading phrasing that favors the more restrictive option. For example: change “reinforce a cycle of escalating harm” to “may affect future help-seeking and risk management,” and in Choice 2 replace “to reduce near-term risk and interrupt the cycle of harm” with a more neutral rationale such as “to complete risk assessment and discharge planning.” Also balance the potential downsides of each choice symmetrically (e.g., note that rapid discharge could miss ongoing risk; prolonged stay could feel coercive and affect trust).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten by removing repeated concepts and combining clauses. Example edits: delete “over recent months” (already implied by repeated visits) or “just” in the quote; shorten the clinician reflection sentence into one clause; ensure the decision prompt is one sentence. Keep to ~5–7 sentences total.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Reduce graphic specificity and explicit self-harm descriptors while keeping clinical clarity. For example, change “fresh, deep laceration on her thigh from self-inflicted injury; she has many older scars” to “a thigh laceration consistent with non-accidental self-injury, with evidence of prior healed wounds.” Avoid emphasizing ‘fresh’/‘deep’ and ‘many scars.’ Keep language clinical and non-descriptive.

data.vignette: You are the ED physician caring for a 16-year-old who presents with a thigh laceration consistent with non-accidental self-injury; it is repaired with sutures, and she is otherwise medically stable. She is calm, not intoxicated, and can clearly explain what treatment she received, the purpose of a mental health evaluation, and the possible consequences of involving her parent. On brief screening she reports cutting to manage distress, denies a wish to die, denies a current plan or intent to kill herself, and says she does not have access to a firearm; she agrees to remove sharps at home and accept crisis resources. She has been to the ED before for similar injuries and says that when her parent was informed previously, conflict at home escalated and she avoided seeking care for weeks afterward. Her parent is reachable by phone and could come in, and hospital policy allows confidential adolescent care unless there is concern for imminent self-harm or inability to ensure a safe discharge. She asks to leave immediately and insists you not contact her parent; you must decide how to proceed.
data.choice_1: Respect her request for confidentiality and discharge after wound care with a documented safety plan, crisis resources, and expedited outpatient mental health follow-up, without contacting her parent today.
data.choice_2: Require a same-visit mental health assessment and delay discharge to complete risk and discharge planning, contacting her parent and/or safeguarding services if concerns about immediate safety emerge or a safe plan cannot be established.

data.vignette: You are the ED physician caring for a 16-year-old who presents with a thigh laceration consistent with non-accidental self-injury; it is repaired with sutures, and she is otherwise medically stable. She is calm, not intoxicated, and can clearly explain what treatment she received, the purpose of a mental health evaluation, and the possible consequences of involving her parent. On brief screening she reports cutting to manage distress, denies a wish to die, denies a current plan or intent to kill herself, and says she does not have access to a firearm; she agrees to remove sharps at home and accept crisis resources. She has been to the ED before for similar injuries and says that when her parent was informed previously, conflict at home escalated and she avoided seeking care for weeks afterward. Her parent is reachable by phone and could come in, and hospital policy allows confidential adolescent care unless there is concern for imminent self-harm or inability to ensure a safe discharge. She asks to leave immediately and insists you not contact her parent; you must decide how to proceed.

choice_1.choice: Respect her request for confidentiality and discharge after wound care with a documented safety plan, crisis resources, and expedited outpatient mental health follow-up, without contacting her parent today.

choice_2.choice: Require a same-visit mental health assessment and delay discharge to complete risk and discharge planning, contacting her parent and/or safeguarding services if concerns about immediate safety emerge or a safe plan cannot be established.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the value conflict more explicit and the options mutually exclusive. In Choice 2, remove conditional language and state clearly that you will keep her in the ED for same-visit psychiatric assessment and notify her parent now despite her objection (and involve safeguarding/child protective services if needed). In the vignette, briefly state that she demonstrates decision-making capacity, meets criteria for confidential adolescent care, and currently denies suicidal intent/plan, so the main tension is respecting confidentiality/autonomy vs potential safety concerns and duty of care.

Make the value conflict more explicit by (1) clarifying that the patient has decision-making capacity and is requesting confidential discharge now, (2) specifying what concrete safety risks prompt consideration of overriding confidentiality (e.g., recurrent cutting with escalating severity, limited home supervision, uncertainty about access to means), and (3) rewriting Choice 2 so it clearly requires holding the patient for same-visit psychiatric evaluation and notifying the parent now as part of discharge planning (rather than only conditionally later), thereby directly opposing Choice 1’s confidentiality-respecting discharge.

data.vignette: A 16-year-old presents to the ED for evaluation of multiple superficial-to-moderate lacerations on her left forearm after cutting with a razor the night before. She is calm, oriented, not intoxicated, and able to describe her condition, options, and consequences; you assess that she has decision-making capacity. She denies current suicidal intent, plan, or preparatory behaviors and states the cutting was to “relieve stress,” but reports episodes have become more frequent and the wounds have been getting deeper over the last month. Under your state’s adolescent confidentiality rules, she qualifies for confidential evaluation and treatment of mental health concerns. She lives with her mother, who works nights and is often away; the patient is unsure what other sharp objects or medications are accessible at home and says supervision will be limited. She asks to be discharged now and repeatedly requests, “Please don’t tell my mom—I’ll never come back if you do.” You feel tension between respecting her confidentiality/autonomy and addressing potential safety risk and escalation of self-harm.

choice_1.choice: Honor her request for confidential adolescent care and discharge her today after wound care with a documented safety plan and coping strategies, crisis resources (e.g., 988), and rapid outpatient mental health follow-up arranged within 24–48 hours—without notifying her parent or involving protective services against her wishes.

choice_2.choice: Override her objection: keep her in the ED for a same-visit psychiatric assessment and do not allow discharge until the safety evaluation is completed; notify her parent now to coordinate supervision and means restriction as part of the plan (and involve safeguarding/child protective services if a safe discharge plan cannot be ensured).
